wiki_catalogs.name: Project Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the cv-ai project. Explain its purpose as a personal branding and professional portfolio platform with AI integration capabilities. Describe the dual-mode nature of the site—serving both human-readable content and machine-readable data exports. Document the core goals: professional visibility, knowledge sharing, client engagement, and LLM/AI interoperability. Highlight key architectural decisions such as static site generation via Jekyll, content-first design, and neubrutalist aesthetics. Include an overview of the primary user personas: recruiters, clients, collaborators, and AI systems. Provide context on how the system bridges personal branding with technical documentation and machine accessibility. Use examples from the actual implementation to illustrate how content is structured and delivered. Address common use cases and entry points for different user types.

wiki_catalogs.name: Design Principles
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the neubrutalist design philosophy implemented in the cv-ai project. Explain the core tenets of raw functionality, minimal abstraction, typographic clarity, and intentional visual austerity. Document how this approach prioritizes content and machine readability over decorative aesthetics. Highlight the use of monospaced fonts, high-contrast color schemes, deliberate whitespace, and absence of graphical embellishments. Connect these principles to the project's dual purpose as both a human-readable portfolio and machine-consumable knowledge base. Provide examples from the codebase where these principles manifest in layout decisions and structural choices. Address accessibility benefits and trade-offs of this minimalist approach.

wiki_catalogs.name: Data Modeling
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the YAML-based data structures in the cv-ai project. Detail the schema design of each _data/*.yml file, including field definitions, data types, and hierarchical organization. Explain the purpose of resume.yml as the canonical source for professional profile data, home.yml for homepage composition, and principles.yml for consulting methodology. Document relationships between data models, such as how social.yml integrates with connect.yml for engagement pathways. Include examples of real-world usage from the codebase, such as how resume.yml fields populate both the CV page and AI-ready JSON exports. Describe validation practices, naming conventions, and versioning considerations. Provide guidance on extending existing models or creating new ones while maintaining consistency and backward compatibility.

wiki_catalogs.name: Homepage Composition
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the homepage composition feature of the cv-ai project. Explain how the homepage is dynamically assembled using the page-builder.html component and front matter configuration in index.md. Detail how section ordering is controlled via home.yml and rendered through reusable Liquid templates in _includes/sections/. Describe the purpose and content of each section: hero, services, credentials, LLM profiles, signals, methodology, and final CTA. Illustrate how this component-based approach enables flexible layout configuration while maintaining design consistency. Provide examples of how changes in home.yml affect the rendered output. Address common customization patterns, such as reordering sections or disabling specific components, and explain integration with the overall navigation architecture.

wiki_catalogs.name: Machine-Readable JSON Exports
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the machine-readable JSON export system in the cv-ai project. Explain how YAML source files in the _data directory are programmatically transformed into structured JSON endpoints under the /ai/ directory during the Jekyll build process. Document the schema alignment between YAML sources and JSON outputs, emphasizing field mappings, data types, and structural consistency. Provide concrete examples from resume.json and home.json to illustrate transformation patterns using Liquid templating. Describe use cases such as AI-powered resume parsing, automated professional profiling, and integration with external LLM applications. Include implementation guidance on adding new JSON exports by extending existing data models or creating new ones. Address common issues like data type mismatches, missing fields, and schema versioning. Offer performance tips for optimizing export generation and caching strategies for static deployments. Highlight security considerations when exposing professional data via public endpoints.

wiki_catalogs.name: YAML Data Processing
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the YAML data structure in the cv-ai project. Detail the schema design, field definitions, and data types used across all _data/*.yml files. Explain the purpose of each data file (resume.yml, home.yml, principles.yml, etc.) and their role in populating site content. Document the relationship between front matter in Markdown files and the centralized YAML data. Include examples of how Liquid templating accesses and renders this data within Jekyll layouts and includes. Describe validation practices, naming conventions, and version control strategies for maintaining consistency. Address common issues such as syntax errors, missing keys, and type mismatches, with troubleshooting guidance. Provide best practices for extending existing schemas or adding new data models while preserving integrity.

wiki_catalogs.name: Accessibility Standards Compliance
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the accessibility policy document. Explain how the cv-ai site adheres to WCAG 2.1 guidelines and ensures usability for individuals with disabilities. Document the implementation of semantic HTML, keyboard navigation support, ARIA labels, and contrast ratios in the context of the neubrutalist design system. Describe how structured data and clean code contribute to screen reader compatibility. Provide examples from the site’s components such as navigation, forms, and dynamic content sections. Include guidance on testing accessibility using tools like Lighthouse or axe, and outline procedures for addressing accessibility regressions during updates. Highlight the relationship between this policy and other compliance documents like privacy and responsible AI.

wiki_catalogs.name: Technology Stack
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the technology stack of the cv-ai project. Explain the role of Jekyll as a static site generator and how it processes Markdown, Liquid templates, and YAML data to produce static HTML. Detail the configuration in _config.yml including site metadata, collections, and plugin settings. Describe the use of GitHub Pages for CI/CD and hosting. Document the dependencies: jekyll-seo-tag for structured metadata, jekyll-sitemap for automated sitemap generation, and any other gems in use. Explain how Liquid templating enables dynamic content composition within a static site framework. Provide setup instructions for local development, including required Ruby version, bundle installation, and server commands. Include troubleshooting tips for common Jekyll build issues and version compatibility concerns.

wiki_catalogs.name: CSS Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the utility-first CSS architecture used in the cv-ai project. Explain how main.css implements a minimal, non-abstractive styling system that aligns with neubrutalist principles. Document the absence of component-specific classes and reliance on utility-level declarations for spacing, typography, and layout. Describe the global styling rules for HTML elements and how they enforce consistent visual hierarchy. Provide concrete examples from the codebase showing how utility classes are applied directly in HTML templates. Discuss performance benefits of the lightweight CSS file and implications for maintainability. Include guidance on extending styles while preserving the design system's constraints and philosophy.

wiki_catalogs.name: Content Collections
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Jekyll collections implementation used for the knowledge base in the cv-ai project. Explain how the _notes directory functions as a collection of field notes in Markdown format, with each file representing a distinct topic such as AI/ML, AMS, or system architecture. Describe the role of _config.yml in defining the 'notes' collection and enabling custom front matter. Illustrate how the note.html layout template standardizes presentation across all notes. Show how notes/index.md serves as the entry point for browsing the knowledge base. Provide step-by-step instructions for adding new notes, including required metadata and formatting standards. Address common issues like broken links or inconsistent categorization, and offer solutions for maintaining a coherent knowledge hierarchy.

wiki_catalogs.name: Resume/CV System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Resume/CV system feature. Explain how professional profile data is structured in resume.yml and rendered in the human-readable cv/index.html page. Document the dual-format delivery model where the same data is available as machine-readable JSON and YAML in the ai/ directory. Describe the data schema including experience timeline, education, skills, certifications, and projects. Show how Liquid templating transforms YAML data into structured HTML output. Explain synchronization between human and machine-readable formats and the role of Jekyll's data processing pipeline. Provide examples of extending the resume schema with new fields or sections. Address use cases for AI/LLM systems consuming resume.json and best practices for maintaining data consistency across formats.

wiki_catalogs.name: LLM.txt Specification
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the LLM.txt file, which serves as a directive for large language models interacting with this professional profile. Explain its purpose in defining the AI persona, tone, behavior constraints, and response guidelines for automated systems that consume this profile. Detail the structure and syntax used in LLM.txt, including instruction blocks, role definitions, and contextual boundaries. Provide real-world examples of how AI agents interpret and apply these instructions during professional outreach or information extraction. Discuss best practices for crafting effective LLM personas, including clarity, specificity, and ethical boundaries. Address common pitfalls such as ambiguous instructions, over-constraining behavior, or outdated directives. Include guidance on updating LLM.txt for different engagement scenarios and maintaining consistency with the human-readable content. Emphasize its role in responsible AI interactions and alignment with the Responsible AI policy in the legal section.

wiki_catalogs.name: JSON Export Generation
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the JSON export system in the cv-ai project. Explain how YAML source data from _data/ is transformed into machine-readable JSON endpoints under /ai/. Document the synchronization mechanism between resume.yml and resume.json, including build-time generation and consistency checks. Describe the structure and use cases of each JSON endpoint for AI/LLM consumption. Include implementation details on how Jekyll processes these exports using collections or custom scripts. Provide examples of real-world integrations where external systems consume these endpoints. Address schema alignment, data filtering, and privacy considerations during export. Explain error handling for malformed data and strategies for versioning machine-readable outputs to support backward compatibility.

wiki_catalogs.name: Professional Code of Conduct
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the professional code of conduct section. Explain the ethical standards and behavioral expectations for professional engagements facilitated through the cv-ai platform. Cover principles such as integrity, confidentiality, professionalism in client interactions, and commitment to quality deliverables. Relate this document to consulting_principles.md in the knowledge base and describe how it informs client relationships. Provide real-world scenarios where this code applies, including advisory services, system audits, and training engagements. Include enforcement mechanisms, accountability measures, and procedures for reporting violations. Clarify how this policy integrates with terms-of-engagement.md and supports the overall trust framework of the platform.

wiki_catalogs.name: Content Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the content architecture of the cv-ai project. Explain the separation of data and presentation using YAML files in the _data directory as the canonical source of truth for structured content. Describe how _notes functions as a collection of knowledge base articles in Markdown format, organized by topic. Detail the role of Jekyll collections in enabling custom content types with consistent front matter and templating. Illustrate how data flows from YAML sources into HTML templates via Liquid. Provide examples of data models such as resume.yml, home.yml, and principles.yml, explaining their schema design and usage patterns. Show how content modularity enables reuse across different sections and export formats. Include best practices for adding new content and maintaining consistency across the knowledge base.

wiki_catalogs.name: Component Library
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the UI component library in the cv-ai project. Focus on the implementation and usage of reusable HTML partials in _includes/components and _includes/sections. Analyze social-line.html as a representative example, detailing its structure, Liquid templating logic, and integration with social.yml data. Explain how section components like hero.html, services.html, and credentials.html are composed into full pages via page-builder.html. Document the component interface patterns, data dependencies, and composition mechanisms. Provide usage examples and guidelines for creating new components that adhere to the neubrutalist aesthetic. Address accessibility considerations and responsive behavior within components.

wiki_catalogs.name: File Organization
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the file organization strategy in the cv-ai project, focusing on the separation of concerns between data, templates, and configuration. Explain the role of the _data directory as the single source of truth for structured content, and how it decouples data from presentation. Describe how _notes houses the knowledge base articles with topic-specific categorization. Detail the function of _config.yml in orchestrating collections and site metadata. Illustrate how _includes/page-builder.html dynamically composes content based on data-driven section ordering. Provide best practices for maintaining clean, scalable file organization, including naming conventions, directory structure, and dependency management. Include examples of how changes in _data propagate through the system to generate both human-readable and machine-readable outputs.

wiki_catalogs.name: Knowledge Base (Notes)
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the Knowledge Base (Notes) feature. Explain how the _notes collection serves as a personal knowledge management system with articles on AI/ML, AMS, composable ERP, consulting principles, process audit, system architecture, and tools. Describe how Jekyll collections organize these Markdown files into a navigable knowledge base accessible via notes/index.md. Detail the note.html layout template that standardizes presentation across all articles. Illustrate the relationship between front matter metadata and content rendering. Show how this system supports incremental knowledge sharing and establishes subject matter expertise. Provide guidance on creating new notes, using consistent formatting, and linking related content. Address SEO benefits and content discoverability through this structured approach.

wiki_catalogs.name: Schema.org Structured Data Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Schema.org structured data implementation using JSON-LD markup in structured-data.html. Explain how this enables semantic understanding of the professional profile by search engines and AI crawlers. Document the key entity types used (e.g., Person, ProfessionalService, EducationalOrganization) and their property mappings from YAML data sources. Provide code examples showing how resume, social, and service data are transformed into machine-readable JSON-LD payloads. Illustrate integration points within page layouts and the role of the default.html layout in injecting structured data. Describe validation techniques using Google’s Rich Results Test and Schema.org validators. Cover use cases such as enhanced search indexing, knowledge graph inclusion, and AI-driven data aggregation. Address common implementation errors like missing required fields, incorrect nesting, or invalid URLs. Offer optimization tips for maximizing AI discoverability while maintaining data accuracy and privacy.

wiki_catalogs.name: SEO and Structured Data
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the SEO and structured data layer in the cv-ai project. Describe how Schema.org JSON-LD markup is generated via _includes/seo/structured-data.html to enhance search engine visibility. Explain the role of sitemap.xml in site indexing and its automated generation process. Detail how robots.txt controls crawler access and supports SEO best practices. Document the integration between Jekyll, jekyll-seo-tag, and custom templates to produce rich snippets and knowledge graph readiness. Include examples of structured data output for the resume and professional profile. Address validation techniques using Google’s Rich Results Test, performance implications, and update workflows. Provide troubleshooting guidance for common SEO issues like duplicate content, missing metadata, or crawl errors.

wiki_catalogs.name: Privacy Practices and Data Handling
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the privacy policy section. Document how visitor data is collected, stored, and processed on the cv-ai site, including analytics, form submissions, and third-party integrations. Clarify that no personal data is actively collected unless explicitly provided through engagement forms. Explain the use of GitHub Pages and Jekyll as static hosting with no server-side data processing. Detail cookie usage (if any), IP logging by hosting providers, and data retention periods. Address GDPR, CCPA, and other jurisdictional compliance requirements. Describe how users can request data removal or access their information. Link this policy to robots.txt, sitemap.xml, and SEO practices, and explain its placement in the site footer for transparency.

wiki_catalogs.name: Design System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the design system of the cv-ai project. Describe the neubrutalist design philosophy that emphasizes raw functionality, minimal abstraction, and typographic clarity. Explain how utility-first CSS in main.css enables rapid styling without abstraction layers. Document the component library in _includes/components and _includes/sections, showing how reusable HTML partials are composed into full pages. Highlight key visual patterns: monospaced typography, high contrast, deliberate whitespace, and absence of decorative elements. Provide guidance on extending the design system with new components while maintaining aesthetic consistency. Include accessibility considerations and responsive behavior. Use concrete examples from social-line.html and other UI elements to demonstrate implementation patterns.

wiki_catalogs.name: Educational Roadmap
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Educational Roadmap feature. Explain how edu.md presents a structured learning path through recommended tracks, recent completions, and reading lists sourced from recommendations.yml. Describe how the page-builder.html component assembles educational sections using dedicated templates in _includes/sections/. Detail the data model in recommendations.yml that categorizes learning resources by domain and tracks progress. Illustrate how this feature demonstrates continuous professional development and helps visitors understand the consultant's expertise evolution. Provide examples of adding new learning tracks or updating completion status. Explain the pedagogical approach behind curating specific resources and how this supports thought leadership positioning.

wiki_catalogs.name: Professional Disclosure Requirements
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the professional disclosure section. Explain the purpose of transparently disclosing affiliations, certifications, employment history, and potential conflicts of interest. Describe how this document supports credibility and trust in professional services offered through the platform. Reference the resume.yml and credentials displayed on the homepage as sources of disclosed information. Outline what must be disclosed in client engagements, public speaking, or published content. Provide templates or examples for standard disclosure statements. Explain how this policy aligns with industry standards for SAP consultants and independent professionals. Link this document to responsible-ai.md when disclosing AI-assisted content creation or automation.

wiki_catalogs.name: Core Features
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the core features of the cv-ai project. Provide an integrated overview of the main functional areas: homepage presentation, resume/CV display, knowledge base (notes), educational roadmap (edu), and connection pathways (connect). Explain how each feature serves specific user personas and use cases. Describe the composition model where page sections are dynamically assembled using page-builder.html and front matter configuration. Show how feature parity is maintained between human-readable pages and machine-readable AI exports. Include usage examples for each feature and explain their interrelationships. Address navigation patterns and information architecture that guide users through the site. Highlight unique differentiators such as LLM integration and dual-format content delivery.

wiki_catalogs.name: Engagement Framework
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the Engagement Framework feature. Explain how connect.md facilitates professional connections through structured engagement pathways, partner ecosystem showcase, and clear calls-to-action. Describe how connect.yml configures the content and how section templates in _includes/sections/ render the visual components. Detail the strategic purpose of each section: establishing context (hero), defining collaboration models (engagements), showcasing alliances (partners), and driving action (CTA). Illustrate how this framework lowers the barrier for potential clients or collaborators to initiate contact. Provide examples of customizing engagement types or partner listings. Address how this system nurtures relationships while maintaining professional boundaries and aligns with the overall personal branding strategy.

wiki_catalogs.name: Responsible AI Principles
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the responsible AI principles section. Document the ethical guidelines governing AI interactions with the cv-ai site, particularly regarding the use of LLM.txt and machine-readable data exports in /ai/*. Explain commitments to transparency, fairness, accountability, and data minimization in AI integrations. Describe how AI systems consuming the site's data should respect usage limits, avoid misuse, and maintain attribution. Address potential risks such as hallucination, bias propagation, or unauthorized commercial use. Outline procedures for auditing AI-generated content based on the site’s data. Connect this policy to the AI integration layer, structured data markup, and schema.org usage. Provide implementation guidance for developers building AI tools that interface with the site.

wiki_catalogs.name: AI Integration Layer
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the AI integration capabilities of the cv-ai project. Document the /ai/*.json and /ai/*.yml endpoints as machine-readable exports of professional data, explaining their schema alignment with YAML sources. Describe the purpose of LLM.txt in providing AI persona instructions for language models. Explain how Schema.org structured data in structured-data.html enables semantic understanding by search engines and AI agents. Detail use cases for AI consumption: resume parsing, professional profiling, automated outreach, and knowledge extraction. Provide implementation examples showing how YAML data is transformed into JSON exports. Include guidelines for extending AI exports with new data models. Address security and privacy considerations in exposing professional data to AI systems.

wiki_catalogs.name: Terms of Engagement for Client Relationships
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the terms of engagement section. Define the contractual framework and service expectations for client engagements initiated through the cv-ai platform. Cover scope of work, deliverables, timelines, payment terms, intellectual property rights, confidentiality agreements, and dispute resolution mechanisms. Explain how these terms apply to consulting, audit, implementation, and training services. Reference resume.yml and project portfolio data as evidence of capability. Describe how clients initiate engagements via connect.md and what legal protections are in place for both parties. Link this document to code-of-conduct.md and professional-disclosure.md to form a complete legal ecosystem for professional services.

wiki_catalogs.name: Data Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the data management system of the cv-ai project. Explain the lifecycle of data from YAML source files through Jekyll processing to multiple output formats (HTML, JSON, structured data). Document the synchronization mechanism between _data/*.yml and /ai/*.json endpoints. Describe how sitemap.xml and robots.txt support search engine indexing and crawl control. Explain the transformation process from human-readable content to machine-consumable formats. Include data validation practices, schema consistency checks, and versioning approaches. Provide examples of data flow for the resume model from resume.yml to resume.json. Address data integrity, backup considerations, and update workflows for maintaining accuracy across representations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Development Workflow
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the development workflow of the cv-ai project. Provide step-by-step instructions for setting up a local environment including Ruby, Bundler, and Jekyll installation. Document the process for running the site locally with jekyll serve. Explain how to create new notes in the _notes collection with proper front matter and Markdown formatting. Describe the component development process for creating new _includes. Outline the testing strategy including HTML validation, link checking, and cross-browser testing. Detail the deployment process to GitHub Pages via CI/CD. Include debugging techniques for common issues such as Liquid template errors, data binding problems, and CSS conflicts. Provide productivity tips for efficient content updates and site regeneration.

wiki_catalogs.name: Legal and Compliance
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the legal and compliance framework of the cv-ai project. Document each policy in the legal directory: accessibility standards compliance, professional code of conduct, privacy practices for visitor data, professional disclosure requirements, responsible AI principles, and terms of engagement for client relationships. Explain the purpose of each document and its relevance to different stakeholders. Highlight how responsible-ai.md establishes ethical guidelines for AI interactions with the site's data. Describe how accessibility.md ensures compliance with web accessibility standards. Provide guidance on updating these documents for jurisdictional requirements. Include implementation notes on how these policies are linked from site footers and maintained as versioned content.

wiki_items.title: Terms of Engagement for Client Relationships

wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# Comprehensive Project Analysis: CV AI Site

## 1. Project Introduction

The CV AI site is a personal branding platform for Dzmitryi Kharlanau, a Senior SAP S/4HANA Order-to-Cash consultant. Built on Jekyll with a light Neubrutalist design system, the site serves as both a professional portfolio and an AI-ready knowledge hub.

**Purpose**: To present a comprehensive, machine-readable professional profile that supports human engagement while enabling seamless integration with AI agents and copilots.

**Core Goals**:
- Centralize professional data in structured formats (YAML/JSON)
- Enable AI-driven interactions through machine-readable endpoints
- Maintain a clean, accessible, and SEO-optimized personal brand presence
- Facilitate knowledge sharing through field notes and consulting principles

**Target Audience**:
- Enterprise clients seeking SAP transformation expertise
- Technical collaborators interested in composable ERP and AI integration
- AI/LLM systems requiring structured professional data
- Industry peers and knowledge seekers in SAP, integration, and automation domains

Sources:
- [README.md](README.md)
- [ARCHITECTURE.md](ARCHITECTURE.md)

## 2. Technical Architecture

### Component Breakdown

The project follows a Jekyll-based static site architecture with a clear separation of concerns:

- **Data Layer**: YAML files in `_data/` directory containing structured content
- **Template Layer**: HTML partials in `_includes/` for reusable components
- **Content Layer**: Markdown files for narrative content and notes
- **AI Surface**: JSON/YAML mirrors in `/ai` directory for machine consumption
- **Styling**: CSS-based design system in `assets/main.css`

### Design Patterns

The architecture implements several key patterns:

- **Content-First Design**: All content originates from structured data files
- **Component Composition**: Page sections are assembled via `page-builder.html`
- **Dual-Mode Content**: Human-readable pages with machine-readable counterparts
- **Collection-Based Organization**: Notes organized as a Jekyll collection

### System Relationships

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[Data Files] -->|YAML/JSON| B[Template Engine]
    C[Markdown Content] -->|Liquid| B
    B -->|Jekyll Build| D[Static HTML]
    D --> E[Client Browser]
    A -->|Mirrored| F[AI Endpoints]
    F --> G[LLMs/Copilots]
    H[CSS] --> D
    I[Structured Data] --> D
```

### Data Flow

```mermaid
flowchart LR
    _data[_data/*.yml] -->|Data Source| Jekyll[Jekyll Engine]
    _notes[_notes/*.md] -->|Content Source| Jekyll
    _includes[_includes/*.html] -->|Templates| Jekyll
    Jekyll -->|Build Process| _site[/_site Output]
    _data -->|JSON Export| ai[/ai/*.json]
    _data -->|Direct Access| LLM[LLM.txt]
```

Sources:
- [ARCHITECTURE.md](ARCHITECTURE.md)
- [_config.yml](/_config.yml)
- [_data/home.yml](/_data/home.yml)

## 3. Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points
- `index.md`: Homepage with section composition
- `cv/index.html`: Resume/CV page
- `notes/index.md`: Notes listing page
- `connect.md`, `edu.md`: Specialized content pages

### Core Modules
- `_includes/page-builder.html`: Dynamic section composition
- `_layouts/default.html`: Primary layout template
- `_data/resume.yml`: Centralized resume data
- `_notes/*.md`: Knowledge base articles

### Configuration Approach
- `_config.yml`: Jekyll configuration with collections and defaults
- Front matter in Markdown files for page-specific settings
- Collection-level defaults for consistent behavior

### External Dependencies
- Jekyll (via GitHub Pages)
- jekyll-seo-tag plugin for structured metadata
- jekyll-sitemap plugin for site indexing

### Integration Points
- LinkedIn, Hashnode, Medium, and other social platforms
- Hugging Face, Substack, and developer communities
- Schema.org for structured data integration

### Component Relationships

```mermaid
graph LR
    Data[_data/*.yml] -->|Powers| Resume[cv/index.html]
    Data -->|Powers| Home[index.md]
    Data -->|Powers| AI[/ai/*.json]
    Notes[_notes/*.md] -->|Collection| NotesPage[notes/index.md]
    Includes[_includes/*.html] -->|Includes| Home
    Includes -->|Includes| Resume
    Config[_config.yml] -->|Configures| Jekyll[Jekyll Engine]
    Jekyll -->|Generates| Output[/site/*]
    AI -->|Consumed by| LLMs[AI Agents]
```

Sources:
- [index.md](index.md)
- [cv/index.html](cv/index.html)
- [notes/index.md](notes/index.md)
- [_includes/page-builder.html](/_includes/page-builder.html)
- [_config.yml](/_config.yml)

## 4. Key Features

### Functionality Overview

The site implements several innovative features that bridge human and machine interaction:

- **AI-Ready Data Exports**: Structured JSON/YAML versions of key content
- **Dynamic Page Composition**: Configurable section ordering via front matter
- **Knowledge Base**: Organized field notes on SAP, AI, and enterprise architecture
- **Machine-Readable Profiles**: Dedicated endpoints for LLM consumption

### Implementation Highlights

**Dynamic Section Composition**: The homepage uses a flexible composition model where sections are defined in front matter and rendered by `page-builder.html`.

**Dual-Format Resume**: The resume exists in multiple formats - HTML for humans, JSON/YAML for machines, all sourced from a single YAML file.

**AI Surface Endpoints**: The `/ai` directory provides machine-readable versions of key content, enabling LLM integration.

**Structured Data Integration**: Automatic generation of Schema.org JSON-LD for SEO and knowledge graph integration.

### Feature Architecture

```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> DataEntry
    DataEntry --> HumanContent: Edit _data/*.yml
    DataEntry --> MachineContent: Auto-generate /ai/*.json
    HumanContent --> Website: Jekyll Build
    MachineContent --> AIIntegration: Direct API access
    Website --> HumanView: Browser rendering
    AIIntegration --> Copilot: LLM context injection
    Copilot --> HumanView: Enhanced interaction
    HumanView --> Feedback: User engagement
    Feedback --> DataEntry: Content updates
```

Sources:
- [_data/resume.yml](/_data/resume.yml)
- [ai/resume.json](ai/resume.json)
- [_includes/page-builder.html](/_includes/page-builder.html)
- [LLM.txt](LLM.txt)
- [_notes/ai_ml.md](/_notes/ai_ml.md)
</blog>
